Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Making Sense of Exceptional Diversity: Coexistence of Many Species in the Mammal Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Life on the planet is not evenly distributed. Though species richness often peaks in the tropics, biological diversity is remarkably wide-ranging at both global and local scales. The tropical oceanic island of Sulawesi, Indonesia contains exceptionally high biodiversity, but the murine rodent (rats and mice) fauna is especially remarkable. Some montane communities containing up to 23 co-occurring murine species, making these the richest communities of closely related mammals on the planet. However, despite indistinguishable habitats, some montane communities contain as few as 10 species. The theory of adaptive radiation predicts that, in order to coexist, species in a community must not rely on the same resource, but instead partition resources through variation in diet, habitat, or both. To understand how resources are partitioned, this collaborative project will generate high-resolution morphological and dietary data from museum specimens in the lab of Dr. Kevin Rowe, Curator of Mammals at Museum Victoria. With these data, this project will test the prediction that members of the most species rich communities are existing on a greater diversity of resources from a wider variety of habitats than the less species rich communities. This project represents an exceptional opportunity for international collaboration while providing evidence that will illuminate how some communities are so diverse, an issue that has puzzled biologists since the earliest days of evolutionary thought.

The theory of adaptive radiation predicts that adequate ecological space must exist for closely related species to co-occur. Calculating the ecological volume occupied in a community can explain how resources are partitioned. The murine rodent (rats and mice) fauna of Sulawesi is remarkable, with some montane communities containing up to 23 co-occurring species. However, this diversity is not distributed equally across the island, and some montane communities contain as few as 10 species. This variation provides a natural experiment in community assembly with the potential to illuminate how these hyperdiverse communities originate and are maintained. This collaborative research will use natural history collections at Museum Victoria to determine the ecological niche volume filled by montane communities across Sulawesi, testing the prediction that local community niche volume will be positively correlated with species richness. Niche volume will be quantified using a novel combination of high resolution skeletal imaging (uCT scans), isotopic analyses of diet, and the structure of digestive tracts, providing an integrated view of how Sulawesi rodents exploit available resources. This collaborative project will determine whether rich communities pack more species into the same ecological volume, or expand total volume, potentially resolving a long-standing, general question in evolutionary ecology.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the summer of 2017 I was awarded an EAPSI fellowship (ID 1713943) to visit Museums Victoria in Melbourne, Australia. The reason for my visit was clear; I study the small mammal communities of the Indo-Australian Archipelago. The diversity found in these faunal communities is exceedingly rich. Perhaps no single location has a higher amount of closely related mammalian species co-occurring in the same community than the island of Sulawesi. It is here on Sulawesi where my Australian host, Dr. Kevin Rowe, spends much of his time, conducting surveys of the small mammal communities across the island. Museums Victoria has an exceptional collection of specimens from Sulawesi that have been collected over the past decade.

 

I am interested in how closely related small mammal (<1kg) species co-occur and coexist in a single space. Particularly, I am asking how does the species composition of a community change as diversity increases. Sulawesi has montane small-mammal communities that range from 10 – 25 species, with no apparent differences in habitat. Do these rich communities just pack species in, or are the additional species in the community doing something different than the “core” members? To answer this question, I am using stable isotope data and microCT scanning of skeletons to interpret the roles of each member of these communities. The stable isotope data provides a proxy for diet, while the skeletal morphology provides a proxy for feeding method and locomotor mode.

 

While in Melbourne I was able to generate whole-body microCT scans of over 50 Sulawesi small mammals from the collections of Museums Victoria. These scans were generated at Monash University, where I met with and was trained by additional researchers. I was also able to take small hair samples from over 150 specimens from Museums Victoria to conduct stable isotopic analyses.

 

The Isotopic data is revealing how members of the species-rich communities are occupying niches that are unoccupied in the less speciose communities. This helps us understand a long-standing question in evolutionary ecology of whether or not communities are limited by the number of species or the number of potential niches. The microCT scans are currently being rendered and segmented into their constituent parts (cranium, mandible, and individual long bones of the arms and legs) so that the shape of these elements can be analyzed using 3D morphometrics and then compared both between species and between communities.

 

In addition to generating large amounts of data, I was able to work closely with researchers and students both at Museums Victoria and Monash University. I have since been in regular contact with several Australian researchers and am currently in the writing stage of a separate project addressing body size and environment in Australian small mammal species. I wish to thank NSF for helping to provide this opportunity.
